content.body:
As mentioned in yesterday's meeting, July's meeting is confirmed as our first hybrid meeting in over two years.  Meaning you can attend in-person if you wish.

The Reflector now has [the July plenary invite,](https://github.com/tc39/Reflector/issues/437) which includes a registration form that anyone who plans to attend in-person **must** complete.

https://github.com/tc39/Reflector/issues/437

https://github.com/tc39/Reflector/issues/437

content.body: in ES6 times, the committee liked to apply "intersection semantics" logic, reasoning that if it's not permitted in all browsers, then it won't affect web compatibility. Such a philosophy didn't turn out to result in something that Chrome could ship in all cases.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: in ES6 times, the committee liked to apply "intersection semantics" logic, reasoning that if it's not permitted in all browsers, then it won't affect web compatibility. Such a philosophy didn't turn out to result in something that Chrome could ship in all cases.

> <@keith_miller:matrix.org> That will print `123` in Safari but `Æ’ f() { f = 123 }` in Chrome

yeah I think Chrome is right here, because you need to make the block-level lexically scoped mutable function declaration as well (this wasn't for web compat but rather for ES6 ideological reasons)

yeah I think Chrome is right here, because you need to make the block-level lexically scoped mutable function declaration as well (this wasn't for web compat but rather for ES6 ideological reasons)

content.body: shu: Also, is resizable TypedArray's ready to ship? Or is it stage 3 but not plz don't ship?
content.formatted_body: shu: Also, is resizable TypedArray's ready to ship? Or is it stage 3 but not plz don't ship?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: shu: Also, is resizable TypedArray's ready to ship? Or is it stage 3 but not plz don't ship?
shu: Also, is resizable TypedArray's ready to ship? Or is it stage 3 but not plz don't ship?

content.body: We really need a stage 3.5 that's this is ready to ship publicly or w/e
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: We really need a stage 3.5 that's this is ready to ship publicly or w/e

content.body: I think what held up Stage 3.5 was both standing disagreements about what the stages mean (now resolved) as well as concerns that requiring consensus on Stage 3.5 would slow our velocity
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think what held up Stage 3.5 was both standing disagreements about what the stages mean (now resolved) as well as concerns that requiring consensus on Stage 3.5 would slow our velocity

content.body: What if Stage 3.5 is just something unilaterally declared by champions based on their understanding of the state of everything?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: What if Stage 3.5 is just something unilaterally declared by champions based on their understanding of the state of everything?

content.body: We could just call it "shippable" and not a stage (so that it wouldn't call into question the meaning of Stage 3 or 4)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: We could just call it "shippable" and not a stage (so that it wouldn't call into question the meaning of Stage 3 or 4)

content.body: it could be documented in the proposal's readme, and just used as a term in meetings, e.g., "Status update: XYZ proposal is shippable, thanks everyone, good work"
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: it could be documented in the proposal's readme, and just used as a term in meetings, e.g., "Status update: XYZ proposal is shippable, thanks everyone, good work"

content.body: but declarations of shippability wouldn't rely on committee consensus--the committee had already done that handoff at Stage 3
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: but declarations of shippability wouldn't rely on committee consensus--the committee had already done that handoff at Stage 3

content.body: wdyt?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: wdyt?

content.body: engines would not be expected to definitely hold off until a champion group declares something shippable, but if an engine wants to be conservative, it can look for that bit, and in the normal case the champions would set the bit in time that things usually match up
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: engines would not be expected to definitely hold off until a champion group declares something shippable, but if an engine wants to be conservative, it can look for that bit, and in the normal case the champions would set the bit in time that things usually match up

content.body: That seems reasonable to me? I'd like an easily searchable list of proposals in that stage though. It could even just be a column in the proposals GH page.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: That seems reasonable to me? I'd like an easily searchable list of proposals in that stage though. It could even just be a column in the proposals GH page.

content.body: yeah that page already has lots of non-consensus-seeking information
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: yeah that page already has lots of non-consensus-seeking information

content.body: shu: The question is, is the proposal definition stable enough to ship, or should engines hold back for possible changes/discussion

content.body: (this is what a "shippable" declaration by a champion would mean)

content.body: well i feel like if i felt that way, or felt it was full of bugs, i wouldn't have asked for stage 3?
